Award.AwardTitle: The Design of Research-in-Instruction Laboratories (RI-Labs) as a Foundation for Transforming Education Research and Professional Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Research-in-Instruction Lab (RI-Lab) model is an analogue of the surgical theater in medical schools and is intended to make expert mathematics teaching visible to and able to be studied by teams of mathematicians, education researchers, experienced and new teachers, and pre-service teachers. The RI-Lab is designed to serve as an incubator for instructional practice and interdisciplinary research into practice. The investigators have developed elementary mathematics labs (EMLs) and replication of the strategy in other locations has seen varying success. This EAGER project is elaborating and specifying the design of RI-Labs to support structured experimental work on instruction in mathematics at the elementary and secondary levels. The researchers are creating and studying secondary mathematics labs (SMLs) as an outgrowth of the EML model, articulating more precisely the research, collaboration, and learning that the larger definition of RI-Labs engender, in an effort to specify the important features of the RI-Labs model, under the hypothesis that once specified, this model will have the potential to enable high-payoff research that could transform education research on a large scale. The study consists of characterizing features of the labs in relation to what the instructional intervention is, how it is studied, and who studies it. Four research questions are being addressed: 1) How and why do different groups of participants use the laboratory class? 2) What work is involved in making elements of teaching visible to and learnable/study-able by observers? 3) What are the affordances and challenges of public engagement with teaching across different groups of participants? 4) What learning opportunities are afforded by an RI-Lab design? New knowledge created by this project is being shared with the NSF Math and Science Partnership and DRK-12 communities and with the public. The ultimate impact of the project, if successful, will be to provide a well-articulated model that can be replicated to advance a new paradigm in education research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A research-in-instruction laboratory provides an arena for intense instructional intervention that is open to professional scrutiny. What makes it a lab, and not just an intervention, is the provision for close observation, analysis, and research by a multi-disciplinary and multi-professional assemblage of observers/participants, a flexible design, and comprehensive, high-quality documentation of the entire process. Historically, medical schools used surgical theaters to make expert practice visible for novices and to support collective observation and analysis of both routine and complex professional practice. “Research-in-instruction laboratories” provide an analogue in education. They represent a potentially transformative resource for research on, and the improvement of, teaching and learning.

In this project, we identified three aspects of research-in-instruction laboratories key to success. 

  1. Physical, technical, and organizational design for seeing, hearing, and capturing teaching
  2. Development of a practice of public teaching
  3. Facilitation of collective work on teaching

The physical and technical design includes everything from organization of the classroom space and a non-distracting observation gallery, to techniques for capturing useful video and audio of shifting arrangements of instructional interactions, to providing live/enhanced video and audio feeds to observers, to processing the documentation and making it available for study and re-use.

Public teaching requires making one’s own teaching studyable by observers. A first feature of such teaching is a practice of providing students with a cocoon that effectively tunes out cameras, microphones, and sundry adults. Second is a practice of supporting observation, such as having students speak loudly enough to be heard by classmates, writing and displaying mathematical work so it can be seen from anywhere in the room, and unpacking explanations adequately to be understood by everyone. The third is about narrating the work of teaching and learning inside instruction, such as pausing to explicitly describe how an activity is designed to support student learning. Narration can make activities and pedagogical reasoning available to observers, while also supporting students’ ability to attend to and make use of instruction.

Observation and collective work on teaching also requires skillful facilitation. Teaching is commonplace in ways that belies its subtlety. Most observers need to be taught how to notice teaching, which in part requires learning to conceptualize teaching. In addition, expertise relevant to understanding mathematics teaching lies with diverse professionals. Working across their different perspectives is aided by: detailed lesson plans augmented to represent public teaching; skillful facilitation of pre-briefs and debriefs; and research projects designed to leverage the experimental options available in a laboratory environment.

John Dewey established a laboratory school in Chicago with the hope that it would serve as the foundation for improving schooling.
